div.p:
The first four notes of this piece are to be played unbroken, with four full and short strokes, and on the fifth one should do a sharp trill in the lowest octave. The following measure is played as written. The first six notes in the fourth measure have to be doubled with octaves, and in the right hand the figure has to be used, that immediately follows
by repercussion by transposition
in the bass:

In the last half of the mentioned fourth measure the right hand has to play six times per crotchet. This is to be done in all similiar cases. Those crotchets are, as you can see, composed of eight notes or divided into the same amount of parts. I remind this, since it might appear strange to the reader, that in just one crotchet he should play six times with the right hand. The fifth bar wants octaves again and in the discant the above mentioned, transposed figure, starting from an e. With that the sixth and seventh measure alternate as well, each in its own tonality.

The eighth bar develops the described interlude three times in ascending degrees in the right hand, while the bass is doubled, in this way:
In the ninth bar the very first motive comes in again. Here the discant can easily find a subtle melody in quavers and the bass can be played full-voiced. In the tenth bar one must not forget the trill on the first note; In the eleventh there is nothing to remind of.

The twelfth bar wants to be played full-voiced in the bass, while the right hand can make use of everything that has been there in the previous measure only by changing the g to a d and continues like that. The thirteenth measure is to be played as written: and the first half of the fourteenth demands one to begin with a little interlude in the discant in the following way:
The same can be done a tone lower in the first half of the fifteenth measure and in the seventeenth measure one only has to observe what has been said in the § 1.

Now it has been indicated in § 3. how to deal with notes as they show up again in m. 21 and m. 22; if, however, somebody wants to do a variation here, it will be even more pleasant to listen to. Once more a trill in m. 22 shall be recommended, that is to say in the low octave. It cannot do harm if somebody wants to try this trill simultaneously in the right hand in sixths.

In m. 25 the simple motive of the beginning occurs once more. Since it can be heard for the fourth time it fairly deserves an ornamentation in the right hand. The usual counter-motive has to be taken from the fourth bar in my opinion, and should be played there as well as here in that way:
From this one can see, that these things are not just whims, empty motives, unordered and wild ideas or dry basses: but everything is connected, there is almost no note to be found that is without relation to the others. After having played to counter-motive a couple of times it may well be varyied for the third and fourth time in that way.

Was has been there in m. 23 comes in again in m. 26, m. 27 and m. 28 etc. with the necessary changes. The last six notes in m. 30 also require a special discant. And then one can play the end as firmly as one's fingers can suffer.
